Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: AERODYNAMIC FLOW DEFLECTOR FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE WIND TURBINES TO INCREASE THE ANNUAL ENERGY PRODUCTION BY 10% AND REDUCE THE LEVELIZED COST OF ENERGY BY 8%
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is in the development of a more efficient wind energy production technology. This technology will make wind energy more economically attractive, improve the energy security of the U.S., create hundreds of jobs and help to reduce coal and natural gas emissions by providing an alternative renewable energy source. An expected reduction in the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) by 8% would help reducing the price of this energy and signing of more wind power purchase agreements. Therefore US citizens would be paying less money out of their pockets on their electric bills. Additionally, big reduction of the cost of wind energy has attracted over $100 billion in private investment since 2008. An expected 10% increase in Annual Energy Production (AEP) would power an extra 1.8 million homes, reduce carbon pollution by 12.5 million metric tons and generate $180 million a year in tax payments to communities. Finally, the innovation proposed in this application has the potential to address both the efficiency demands of wind farm owners (reducing the break-even times) and providing a disruptive design innovation to turbine manufacturers for them to have a sustainable competitive edge.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will address challenges related to aerodynamic efficiency of wind turbines. It focuses on developing aerodynamic flow deflectors to be mounted on the wind turbine blades. These can be incorporated into new wind turbine designs or retrofitted onto the thousands of currently operating turbines to increase their efficiency. By introducing the proposed flow deflector, the radial component of velocity of the incoming flow is redirected to produce an additional amount of torque and generate the extra power. From discussions with leading wind energy companies, there is a general agreement that this could be a game changer and one of the biggest improvements in wind turbines to date, but large scale field test validation is needed. Therefore, the key technical challenge to bring the technology to market that would be addressed in Phase I is to perform a field test of the flow deflectors in a large scale turbine (1-20 meter diameter) under realistic environmental conditions. The main goal for Phase I is to demonstrate the substantial power increase (AEP >2-3%) while reducing the cost of energy (LCOE >2%) when retrofitting a large scale commercial turbine with the proposed technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lowering the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) is the priority for all wind energy segments. Due to the high capital requirements for these structures, any reduction in LCOE through turbine efficiencies will pay significant dividends in the Wind Farm Owners’ return-on-investment (ROI). Thereby increasing the overall competitiveness of the wind energy sector. Our deflectors technology innovation has the potential to address both the efficiency demands of wind farm owners (reducing time until ROIs) as well as to provide a disruptive design innovation to wind turbine manufacturers, providing them a sustainable competitive edge (reduced LCOE). An important emphasis to make regarding this technology is that it can be retrofitted to existing turbines as well as incorporated into the design of newly manufactured blades without increasing their diameters

During the NSF SBIR Phase I, the aerodynamic deflectors were tested in two distributed commercial turbines (5kw and 50kW) at one of the NREL Regional Testing Centers (Windawrd Engineering). All data was collected and processed following IEC 61400-12-1 power performance standards. These third party measurements showed that the Annual Energy Production (AEP) increased substantially (2-8%) when retrofitting the deflectors into both commercial turbines. In addition, the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) reduced substantially (1-6%). Additionally, the technology has shown to scale up seamlessly. From wind tunnel measurements (0.5m rotor diameter) to field tests (20m rotor diameter), we have observed large AEP increments.

Our product leads to more efficient wind energy production while reducing the cost of energy. This will make wind energy more economically attractive, improve the energy security of the U.S, create hundreds/thousands of jobs, and help to reduce coal and natural gas emissions as an alternative renewable energy source.

By using our technology over the 48,000 operating utility wind turbines in the U.S. (65,879 MW or 190 million MWh/year), a 10% AEP increase will generate these benefits:

  • Power an extra 1.8 million homes
  • Create hundreds/thousands of new jobs
  • Reduce carbon pollution by 12.5 million metric tons
  • Provide $180 million a year in tax payments to communities
  • Increase wind farm revenue by 10% and profits over lifetime by 28% (and an excellent opportunity to reduce the price of energy).

This technology also enhances wind turbine aerodynamics understanding from a more 3-dimensional point of view. Most wind turbine designs are based on 2D theories that assume 3D losses. Theories are then modified to include 3D empircal corrections. Our technology take advantage of the 3-dimensinal behavior of the velocity to increase the output power and therefore reduce those losses.
